title: 112_hr3291
content: The Act titled "Healthy Foods for Healthy Living Act" promotes greater consumption of fresh fruits, vegetables, and other healthy foods in low-income communities through Department of Agriculture grants. The Secretary of Agriculture may grant funds to community-based organizations or local redevelopment agencies to expand access to fresh fruits and vegetables in low-income communities. Grant recipients can use the funds to purchase equipment, hire personnel, and promote healthier food alternatives as defined by the Department of Agriculture. The Department of Agriculture defines healthier food options for low-income communities, including dairy and non-dairy alternatives, pure fruit juices, and products with no transfat. Consumer education activities aim to promote these products and inform residents about the benefits of healthy living. Grants under this program are capped at $100,000 and community-based organizations, such as schools and food banks, are eligible. Authorization of appropriations is also included. Authorization of Appropriations: $5,000,000 is authorized for the Secretary to implement this section in fiscal year 2012. SEC. 3. COVERAGE OF ADDITIONAL PRIMARY CARE AND PREVENTIVE SERVICES UNDER THE MEDICARE AND MEDICAID PROGRAMS. The Medicare Program now includes additional primary care and preventive services such as services for obesity prevention and treatment, supervised exercise sessions, exercise stress testing for prescriptions, and lifestyle health improvement education. The Medicare Program now includes additional primary care and preventive services like lifestyle health improvement education and culinary arts education for proper nutrition. Conforming amendments have been made to allow for these services to be performed more frequently. The Medicare Program has been amended to include additional preventive services defined in section 1861(ddd). The Medicaid Program has also been updated to cover additional preventive services not previously included. These changes will take effect on the first day of the first calendar quarter after the enactment of the Act. The Act's amendments will take effect on the first day of the first calendar quarter after enactment, regardless of the status of implementing regulations.
